DIVERSE WORKFORCE—
                    BEST PRACTICES FROM UTILITIES
Harnessing the Power of Diversity and Inclusion
 


July 24 - 25, 2007 / San Francisco, CA

OVERVIEW


As the baby boomer generation approaches retirement, utilities have recognized the dual challenges of maintaining
              crucial experience and knowledge, while recruiting, developing and retaining a 21st century workforce. Some proactive
              organizations have identified and implemented strategies and tactics to meet these challenges. Knowledge retention
              programs and joint efforts with local colleges and universities are underway. Enhanced recruitment and retention
              programs are also being developed to fill the workforce with employees that represent the communities they serve. 
 
Utilities recognize the challenges and opportunities of the changing demographics. Those utilities that implement a
                      strategic diversity process will be able to create a strong, high-performing organization. These companies are making
                      a business case to manage and leverage diversity by linking it to their organizational business plan. Leadership’s true
                      understanding of, and commitment to diversity and inclusion sets the strategic direction for the organization and is key to
                      success. Leadership must transition from diversity as a program to an integral component of daily business operations. 
 
Diversity and inclusion are not only key from a workforce perspective, but from a community and marketplace perspective
                      as well. Work with community organizations through volunteer efforts or foundation funding become essential
                      components of the extension into the service area community. As one tactic, Supplier Diversity also enhances the
                      economic development within the community and demonstrates good corporate citizenship.
  
This conference will provide insight into the unique path utilities are taking towards a high-performing, diverse and
                      inclusive workforce culture. Starting with some of the basic components of a diversity process, and working through
                      examples from existing programs that are thriving, this conference will highlight the initiatives that generate inclusiveness
                      as a key to utilities successfully competing in the marketplace.
 
Who Should Attend:
 
Utility CEOs, vice presidents and managers interested in creating or promoting diversity efforts in their organization

 Human resource and diversity professionals interested in learning more about diversity programs in the utility industry
 Diversity consultants who would like to learn more about efforts in the utility industry
 Non-profit foundation managers wanting to become more involved in the diversity efforts of the organization
 Other managers who will be working with the utilities emerging diverse workforce:
                        
 Generation, T&D operations/maintenance/construction
 Strategic planning
 IT
 Marketing
 Communication
 Staffing and recruitment
 Community and public relations
 Career development
 Employee training
 Organizational development
 Power operations
 Customer service
 Supplier Diversity programs 



Why Attend?
 
Several factors are coming together to change the nature of the utility’s workforce. This conference will provide exposure
                      to some of the significant issues in creating a diversity program, some of the issues utilities have faced when pursuing
                      diversity efforts, and ideas to move diversity efforts toward establishing a high-performing organization. 
 
What Will You Learn?

An overview of creating a diversity and inclusion process
 The difference between inclusion and diversity
 How to include traditional utility employees in diversity and inclusion efforts
 What is a Diversity Council and how does it promote the strategic development process?
 How to build community in the workplace by supporting the service area community
 What does an excellent Supplier Diversity program look like?
 How to use non-profits in your diversity program
 How to effectively use affinity groups to establish diversity
 What is “Diversity Thinking”?
 What are some low-cost options to establishing a diversity program?
 How to institutionalize diversity within your organization to establish high performance
 How to incorporate diversity into succession planning
 What is a diversity scorecard?
